title: 109_s3800
content: The Act titled "Stop Assistance to Counterfeiters Act" requires certification for trafficking in goods or services with counterfeit marks under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The "Stop Assistance to Counterfeiters Act" mandates certification for individuals seeking US assistance until they submit a certification for that fiscal year. Assistance to foreign governments is exempt from this requirement. The Act defines a "counterfeit mark" as per section 2320 of title 18, US Code. The term 'person seeking United States assistance' refers to individuals or organizations seeking assistance directly from the United States or receiving it through agreements. The term 'traffic' is defined as per section 2320 of title 18, US Code. A certification is required from individuals seeking US assistance annually. The text chunk states that assistance provided must not be used for trafficking counterfeit goods, by individuals with previous infringement issues, or for importing products developed with the assistance in violation of specific laws. The text chunk outlines requirements for certification submission before receiving United States assistance, including evidence of the right to use intellectual property and compliance with relevant laws. The President can suspend or terminate assistance if it is used for activities violating certification. Waivers can be granted for national security reasons with notification to Congress. The President can suspend or terminate assistance for violations, with waivers allowed for national security reasons. Certification requirements apply to assistance provided after fiscal year 2006.
